item.title: 2024 in Review
item.author: Noah Jacobus
item.description:
Hi there! It‚Äôs been a bit.

If I felt like last spring/summer was busy with speaking prep for Config 2023, this one felt doubly so. Also I was holding off on posting because of (unsuccessfully) trying to redesign this place for the last 11 months. Anyway here are some things that happened since the last time I wrote in January:

Into the Awesomeverse

I helped launch and maintain our Kickstarter campaign for Web Awesome in the spring! I‚Äôd heard folks say that doing crowdfunding is way more work than you think it‚Äôs gonna be, and they weren‚Äôt kidding. Thankfully the Font/Web Awesome team is full of people much smarter than I am to help field questions and keep things compelling.

In addition I got to design lots of swag, some of which only just reached the US. Physical products are no joke! Shouts out to the fine folks at Cotton Bureau for handling fulfillment and helping get things across the finish line. Keep an eye out for extras in our CB shop once all the backer rewards go out.

In other Awesome news, we released all our remaining Sharp and Duotone styles, and brought Zach/11ty and Lea Verou on board. A big year ‚Äî with even more big things coming in 2025... ü§´

Chunk

I wrapped up version 3 of my Chunk icon library! This was a big effort for li‚Äôl ol‚Äô me ‚Äî chipping away at an icon here and there after my kid went to sleep. Last year I‚Äôd pitched the improvements to Figma as part of their Creator Grant program and got accepted. Thankfully a concrete deadline for finishing the update wasn‚Äôt included in the contract, because it took me a few months longer than initially anticipated üòÖ But along with completion came the chance to show off all my new pretties at Config 2024 ‚Äî so I popped into Keynote of all things and whipped up a short promotional video:

Config

The Big Fig‚Ñ¢ was a bit odd this year. Overcrowding, registration issues, and the overarching gloom of AI cruft cast a pall over the event. But the time, attention, sleepless nights, and love the Figma team put into every detail was also so readily apparent I really can‚Äôt fault anyone for the hiccups.

A huge highlight for me, though, was the people ‚Äî a recurring theme for this year in general. I got to spend some top drawer quality time with my internet bud Alex eating burritos and perusing the Art of Noise exhibit at SFMoMA. I also got to show off our Font Awesome keycaps on a silver Typface Univers to anyone with a pulse and the slightest interest in computer input devices.

Issues aside, I‚Äôm planning on attending again in 2025 ‚Äî if for no other reason than to get a burrito at Garaje and talk about video games and life goals with Alex again.

XOXO

It‚Äôs a weird time to be online.

That was a recurring theme at the very last XOXO festival ‚Äî a place dedicated to the people who make things on the internet. And it was a theme I felt very keenly in a different way because it was my first and last time attending. I hadn‚Äôt even really been aware of XOXO until it had already been canceled in early 2020; but looking back through festival videos and first-hand accounts, I knew I had to get there if Andy & Andy ever did it again.

By all accounts, this last hurrah was a stripped-back version of its former self: fewer days, fewer events, fewer musical guests. But that also meant it could be a more intimate and intentional space for those who‚Äôd come to call XOXO a second family.

As the kids say, the vibes were immaculate. (Do kids say that anymore?) Even having never attended an XOXO before, I felt integrated immediately ‚Äî no doubt helped by the general air of inclusion around the whole event. A sensible COVID policy? In my 2024? It‚Äôs more likely than you think.

A few of my favorite talks: Cabel Sasser, Molly White, Craig Mod, Gita Jackson, Sarah Jeong, Kim Belair, Erin Kissane, and Dan Olson.

And some of the lovely folks I got to spend time with (including friends new and old): Ben Krogh, Arun Venkatesan, Christa Mrgan (sorry I didn‚Äôt hear your karaoke), Jez Burrows, Nathan Peretic, Lynn Fisher, Paul Straw, Paul Carroll, Susan Lin, and Taylor Moore.

I wish I could drink that pear shrub again.

Creative Works East

While stranded in the airport en route to Config (and missing out on a dinner at The French Laundry ü•≤), I got a message from Josh Horton asking me if I wanted to run an icon workshop at the upcoming Creative Works East in Brooklyn. I‚Äôd always wanted to attend CW in the past but the timing never worked out with other travel commitments. So I said yes!

I‚Äôve worked up lots of different icon education materials over the years in print and video form, but I‚Äôd never gotten to do a long, in-person workshop like this before. Not to mention those were free ‚Äî so the added pressure of making it a good value for the people paying to hear me talk about small pictures was quite daunting.

Unfortunately working on my presentation and materials every day for 3.5 months ‚Äî overthinking and over-designing every single aspect ‚Äî really stressed me out. I‚Äôm an absolute weirdo whose brain thinks that its first attempt at something new should be perfect. And giving myself a little slice of each day to worry about perfection and ‚Äúgiving people their money‚Äôs worth‚Äù really put my psyche through the wringer.

But overall, it went well. I only had 4 registrants (conference attendance as a whole was low), but they were super engaged and asked fantastic questions. Having never run a 3-hour affair in the past, I ended up mistiming the pacing and had to rush through some bits to pack in as much info as I could. After a couple years of multiple speaking gigs, I‚Äôd like to lay low for a bit. But I would love to rework some of the Creative Works material into something more streamlined and useful in the future.

Again, this one really ended up being about the people. Getting to spend more time with my buds Daniel Seong, Julia Steffen, Rogie King, and Helena Zhang; and getting to meet internet friends Lisa Champ, Jeff Sheldon, and Kelli Anderson for the first time.

There‚Äôs more that could be said about each of these (and maybe I will), but I need to warm back up to this whole blogging thing. If there‚Äôs anything particular you‚Äôre curious about, let me know below with an electronic mail! ‚úåüèª

item.title: Elantri-Fix
item.author: Noah Jacobus
item.description:
Back in 2015 during my second read-through of Brandon Sanderson‚Äôs Mistborn trilogy, I got the itch to make my own little iconographic representations of the base Allomantic metals and their powers. My goal was to strip things down to some simple visual language:

It was a fun and quick little project ‚Äî and I didn‚Äôt think much about it until last year when Isaac Stewart, art director for Dragonsteel, reached out to me. Turns out they were looking for some nerdy folks to help design items for the Year of Sanderson swag boxes, and my name had resurfaced! Isaac already knew I loved Brandon‚Äôs books, and he‚Äôd gathered some of my previous work as reference for a specific project from the world of Sel: bandages

Some background

The world of Sel is the home of Elantris and The Emperor‚Äôs Soul within Brandon‚Äôs literary Cosmere. I specifically don‚Äôt want to spoil much of the former, but it involves a decrepit city full of people who are doomed to accumulate minor injuries until they go mad. Fun!

We started with the above reference image and a brief:

Purpose/Tone: A bit of a spoof. In Elantris, Sarene brings items into the city to help the Elantrians inside who are suffering the Shaod. This box has band-aids intended to be used by Elantrians on their cuts that don‚Äôt heal.

With just these couple prompts, a template from the manufacturer, and some color ideas (also since it‚Äôd been a while, a quick re-read of parts of Elantris), we were off to the races.

Figuring it out

I dove into paper and pencil first. As usual, this was to get as many ideas (especially the bad ones) out of my brain as quickly as possible ‚Äî but I don‚Äôt really have a consistent and organized way to handle these. Years of attending design conferences have left me with more little notebooks than I could ever use, so I just grab whatever‚Äôs handiest üòÖ

I took this step only as far as I needed to before starting to digitally rough out digital layouts ‚Äî I work in Figma every day for my job at Font Awesome so I‚Äôm pretty speedy at this point, especially for such simple stuff. Eventually, 3 different directions and some guiding principles emerged:

  • Spoofy portmanteau product names like: Elant-Fix, Reo-lief, ‚ÄúSarene‚Äôs Own‚Äù brand, Widow‚Äôs Trial Bandages
  • Prominent use of Aon Rao
  • Blues, browns, and golds
  • ‚ÄúProduct of Teod‚Äù stamped on the bottom
  • ‚ÄúEternal life of scrapes and bruises got you down in the dumps? Next time you slip on some slime, look no further than ____!‚Äù
  • Small print disclaimers

Years of working at a product design agency taught me to never hand over a lick o‚Äô work without context, so I also put together a little presentation to explain my choices:

Drawing the bits

By and large, Isaac and the team loved them straight away. There were some minor tweaks to make (like adjusting the name from Elant-Fix to Elantri-Fix), but the third concept clearly won. Even my written copy got to stick around!

But I needed to start working on some of the fiddlier, ornamental bits ‚Äî so back to the sketchbook I went:

The visuals for the borders and the big, central Aon Rao were first to settle, and helped inform probably my favorite bit to make: the title treatment.

For other non-title text, I turned to my favorite place to go type shopping: Future Fonts. More specifically, the inherent strength and stylish flair in East of Rome‚Äôs excellent Auroc.

Thanks to planning everything in Figma, I was able to make the title lockup and all other reusable bits as component instances. Any changes I made to the main component would cascade through the entire layout and save me a bunch of time.

Various components also came in handy when making the bandages themselves ‚Äî all of the Aons could carry over, along with colors and some ornamental elements. So I really only had to a bandage component once, and could swap in the rest on the fly.

Making it real

As the deadline loomed for wrapping things up, I was in the midst of helping moving my parents across the country. So I didn‚Äôt have a ton of extra brain bandwidth to come up with a comprehensive recommendation, but I did offer the Dragonsteel team my thoughts on some fancy finishes and processes we could use during fabrication.

Final designs were approved, files sent, and fees paid (the fastest turnaround I‚Äôve seen)! Then I waited for 10 months. Manufacturing ain‚Äôt easy!

The new year arrived, and I followed Brandon‚Äôs video updates on YouTube to hear any news of my precious li‚Äôl adhesive friends and their flip-top aluminum house. Then lo and behold, the YouTube unboxing videos began to appear!

I really can‚Äôt overstate how much all these videos warmed my heart. Everyone was very complementary and really seemed to love the cheeky tone and Easter eggs tucked throughout the designs.

Both the tin and the bandages came out even better than I‚Äôd hoped! Isaac, the Dragonsteel team, and the manufacturer knocked my vision out of the park, and I couldn‚Äôt be happier with the result. They even gave me a few copies of my own to squirrel away or give to friends and family.

And now, for some more pictures because I just enjoy looking at them üòÑ

item.title: My Famicase 2023
item.author: Noah Jacobus
item.description:
It‚Äôs the most wonderful time of the year again, the My Famicase Exhibition!

I mentioned this briefly in the last Enjoyment Roundup; but for more context, My Famicase is a little show put on every spring by Satoshi Sakagami of METEOR gallery in Nishi-Ogikubo, Tokyo. Every year, folks from all over the world get to design brand new, imaginary games for the Super Famicom system (Japan‚Äôs version of the Super Nintendo) and have them displayed on physical cartridges for all to see! I‚Äôve had the honor of participating in 3 previous exhibitions, but took last year off due to having zero extra creativity.

A sweet & sticky space mystery

As with most of my previous entries, the idea for the name came first. I have a note on my phone where I workshop Famicase ideas throughout the year so that once I realize ‚Äúoh dang I better get started‚Äù in February or so, I can get started without too much stress. Gelatinous Cubicle (2021‚Äôs entry) was born from this list, and I‚Äôm excited about some promising candidates for forthcoming years üòé

S‚ÄôMARS quickly rose to the top this time, but I needed to figure out what it meant. Would it be about a planet made of gooey, burned confectionary? Maybe some sort of saccharine puzzle game? Thankfully, a rewatch of Sunshine and a YouTube playthrough of the Dead Space remake coincided to give the idea some loose structure.

As always, things start with some rough sketches. I typically do this only as long as it takes me to scratch out a few ideas or type lockups that I like.

There‚Äôs something hungry out there...

I knew I wanted to do something with a sci-fi technical schematic look, with text overlaid using some sort of transparency or blending mode. I made the ship first, but it was a bit too complicated at first to have text reliably and legibly sit on top. But after 5 iterations or so, I hit a general layout and color scheme (inspired by NASA, ofc) that worked well.

I remade and recolored my old Famicom cartridge vector template in Figma, and voila!

The final title treatment, especially, was a blast to develop. I knew I wanted something tech-y and somewhat interconnected, but earlier NASA-esque explorations didn‚Äôt pan out the way I wanted. Plus, the juxtaposition of such stark and rigid lettering and an ooey-gooey treat is kind of funny.

With Famicase entries, though, the art is only half of it. You‚Äôre also encouraged to write a short game description that will go onto the website and exhibition booklet. It could be anything, which is intimidating! But some of my aforementioned media consumption helped crystallize into this:

Mallow Core: offline. Graham Panel Array: unresponsive. Choc Strut Integrity: compromised. We‚Äôre 84 million miles from home, and there‚Äôs something hungry out there.

I could keep writing about this stuff for a while, but honestly I didn't document as much of the process or rejected concepts as I‚Äôd hoped üòÖ If you‚Äôd like to read more sometime about these (like using extensive Figma components for the first time while making Gelatinous Cubicle) or anything else Famicase-related, hit that email link below.

item.title: Job Awesome
item.author: Noah Jacobus
item.description:
One year ago today, I started working at Font Awesome. I‚Äôd already been planning on writing a bit about the experience and how it‚Äôs been different; but last month, Lynn Fisher posted an excellent list of things she wants from a job. The earnestness of her words helped clarify my own thoughts and put some things in perspective.

But first, a little background. I used to work remote at a Canadian design agency. In the last couple years out of my 7 working there, I regularly kept an ear to the ground about new opportunities. Judging by LinkedIn and read.cv profiles, 7 years is an eternity in tech ‚Äî so I suppose it makes sense that things started to stagnate. I had a terrific manager, but the company didn‚Äôt really know what to do with me as one of the only design specialists. Very much a ‚Äúthe clients love you and we value what you do‚Äù but also a ‚Äúwe forgot to promote you for the things you were already doing‚Äù situation. Anyway, I was tired of it. And thanks to Lynn‚Äôs list, it‚Äôs much easier now to identify some key things I felt were missing:

  • Work that benefits the people who receive it. Benefit is hard to gauge with super quick, 2-week engagements. You do your best, explain your work‚Äôs worth and how it fits into the larger project, and cross your fingers and toes that it‚Äôll get used correctly (or at all).
  • A team small enough to know everyone personally. By the time I left, we were well over 100 spread across multiple departments and countries around the world. Upside: lots of diverse clientele & coworker experiences. Downside: it was impossible to know everyone, much less work with them. Kind of a rough deal in terms of remote working relationships. Plus, the specialist ‚Äúteam‚Äù was so siloed and haggard we couldn‚Äôt actually get together and plan how to address issues we all faced.
  • The autonomy to make small and big decisions about my work.
  • The ability and opportunity to share my work publicly. NDAs blow.
  • Very few meetings, used effectively.
  • Work that makes me come alive. Aside from all the rest, one of the final nails in the coffin was the company‚Äôs growing involvement in web3 and crypto client projects. I voiced my concerns about that whole disaster multiple times but was still assigned to them anyway.

So one year in, has Font Awesome been different?

A lot.

We follow the tenets of Shape Up, writing pitches and breaking work into digestible, 6-week chunks called ‚Äúsplits.‚Äù And in between these splits, we have 2-week cooldowns to work on fun things, fix random bugs, or learn new skills! A far cry from the blistering pace of agency client work. Let‚Äôs revisit some of that list:

  • Work that benefits the people who receive it. Everything at FA is based around icons, their implementation, and what our users and subscribers need ‚Äî so I don‚Äôt need to constantly ‚Äúsell‚Äù my skills or convince stakeholders that I belong at the table. Refreshing! Also being able to really dig in on something and tinker and revise until it works beats the heck out of fortnightly context whiplash.
  • A team small enough to know everyone personally. As of this writing, there are 18 of us. Even with everyone working remote, it's soooo much easier to build relationships when you can remember everyone's name. Plus we all hang out twice a year to noodle on new ideas, play D&D, and eat cookies.
  • The autonomy to make small and big decisions about my work. Everybody gets to have a say in what they work on. Pitches are written prior to each split outlining the planned work ahead and any foreseen potential pitfalls, and folks are welcome to help shape that direction and help hammer the scope down into something manageable.
  • The ability and opportunity to share my work publicly. I love talking about icons! I‚Äôve done a fair share of written and video content about them in the past, and now I get to keep doing it.
  • Very few meetings, used effectively I have about one meeting a week ‚Äî¬†that‚Äôs it. And it‚Äôs a pretty chill roundup of how everyone‚Äôs week has been.
  • Work that makes me come alive. I won‚Äôt go all Dani Rojas and say that ‚Äúicons are life,‚Äù but I will say that working at Font Awesome has allowed all the parts of myself outside the 9‚Äì5 to more fully come alive. I haven‚Äôt had the Sunday Scaries once this past year. I‚Äôve had spare creativity to use for freelance and side projects (like this blog!). Lower anxiety levels means better quality time with my family.

Something our CEO Dave likes to talk a lot about is ‚Äúwork as a means to an end.‚Äù While it‚Äôs great to enjoy what you do for a living (and I‚Äôm incredibly blessed that I do), it should be just that: for living. Jobs should be tools to enable you to live the life you want when you‚Äôre not on the clock. (P.S. We‚Äôre hiring!)

Cheers to one year and here‚Äôs to many awesome more ‚öë

Thanks to Em for proofreading

item.title: Enjoyment Roundup 002
item.author: Noah Jacobus
item.description:
More things have been enjoyed! I‚Äôve also been tinkering with some style updates to the site and blog, but they‚Äôre not ready for primetime quite yet. I‚Äôd thought my design was pretty settled for a while, but as always Marcotte‚Äôs Law holds true.

  • üìñ The Politics of Design by Ruben Pater

    You are privileged. Just reading this sentence makes you part of the 85% of the world population that is literate, the 20% that understands English, and the 40% that has access to the internet.

    I‚Äôm not quite all the way through yet, but it‚Äôs a both brisk and brusque read with a welcome tone. Adding Ruben‚Äôs Caps Lock to my reading list next.

  • üéµ The Record by boygenius

    Julien Baker, Phoebe Bridgers, and Lucy Dacus are at it again. No words, just listen. Full album comes out March 31.

  • üåê My Famicase Exhibition

    The most wonderful time of the year is coming soon! Hosted by METEOR in Nishiogikubo, My Famicase is a celebration of the Super Famicom game system (Japan‚Äôs version of the Nintendo SNES). Every spring, designers from around the world get to make up brand new games as if they‚Äôd been made for the Super Famicom, then see their work displayed on actual cartridges in METEOR‚Äôs gallery space. I was too busy to participate last year, but you better believe I‚Äôm locked and loaded for 2023 üòé

  • üì∫ Shape Island

    I‚Äôve long enjoyed the Jon Klassen‚Äôs books (We Found a Hat and The Rock from the Sky are favorites in our house), but I wasn‚Äôt as familiar with his Shape stories written with Mac Barnett.
